turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You think we're being set up?--Christ, Deep Throat tells you last night that the letter came from inside the White House and up traipses Marilyn naming names.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It makes a crazy kind of sense-- remember that initiation rite they have at the White House? Each new member of the President's staff has to prove his guts by getting an enemy of Nixon.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You think this was Clawsen's initiation?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Could have won him a fraternity paddle with a White House seal.  God knows it worked.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: He'll give us a sworn statement.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: We're inside the White House now.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --That cash fund that financed the sabotaging of the Democrats--five guys had control--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --Mitchell, Stans, Magruder, Kalmbach--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --we're working on the last guy now and we're going all the way--that fifth man was Haldeman.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I think that's him.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Haldeman.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Nah.  Maybe.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What if I went up and introduced myself--think he'd slug me?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Well, we are trying to ruin his life.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It's nothing personal, though.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Same as Magruder, I don't like it when they turn out to be human.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I wish we were investigating Attila the Hun.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Maybe we are...

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --Jesus--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --he said John Haldeman, not Bob Haldeman--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --Sloan told the Grand Jury--he answered everything they asked him-- that means there's a record somewhere--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --and the FBI confirms--what more do you need?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: How many fucking sources they think we got?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --Deep Throat won't confirm--I never thought he was scared of anyone, but he's scared of Haldeman.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I know a guy in the Justice Department who was around the Grand Jury.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --We got twenty minutes to deadline--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Woodward?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Hmm?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What was the mistake? Do you think it's been rigged, all along the way, leading us on so they could slip it to us when it mattered? They couldn't have set us up better; after all these months our credibility's gone, you know what that means?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Only everything...

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You overslept?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Goddamnit!--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I finally got through to Sloan--it was all a misunderstanding that we had: he would have told the Grand Jury about Haldeman, he was ready to, only nobody on the Grand Jury asked him the goddamn question.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: So I guess you could say that we screwed up, but we weren't wrong.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: What does it say?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: John N. Mitchell, while serving as US Attorney General, personally controlled a secret cash fund that--

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: --jeeeeeeesus--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --fund that was used to gather information against the Democrats--

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: --jeeeeeeesus--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --according to sources involved in the Watergate investigation. Beginning in the spring of 1971--

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: --jeeeeeeesus--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --almost a year before he left the Justice Department--

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: --jeeeeeeeeesus--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --to become President Nixon's campaign manager on March 1, Mitchell personally approved withdrawals from the fund--

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: --all that crap, you're putting it in the paper? It's all been denied. You tell your publisher--tell Katie Graham she's gonna get her tit caught in a big fat wringer if that's published. Good Christ! That's the most sickening thing I ever heard.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Sir, I'd like to ask you a few--

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: --what time is it?

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Morning or night?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Night.

turns.speaker: MITCHELL
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Look, you've been jerking my chain all day. If there's some reason you can't talk to me--like the fact that you've already leaked everything to The New York Times--just say so.

turns.speaker: DARDIS
turns.text: Listen, I've got a dinner--can't we do this tomorrow?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I'm on deadline.

turns.speaker: DARDIS
turns.text: You want Barker's phone stuff or his money stuff?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Whatever.

turns.speaker: DARDIS
turns.text: I'll never get out of here in time.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: The telephone calls... we know about that.

turns.speaker: DARDIS
turns.text: The rest is Barker's bank records. It's mostly the eighty-nine thousand in Mexican cashier's checks--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --yeah, that was in The Times this morning.

turns.speaker: DARDIS
turns.text: I never could figure just who this Dahlberg was.  Think it might be anything?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: This?  Naw...

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Sorry.  Now if it was Hunt you were interested in--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --Howard Hunt?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Sure. Him I liked, he was a very nice person. Secretive too, traveled all over, but a decent man.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Any idea what he did?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Oh, the scuttlebutt for awhile was he was investigating Kennedy--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --Teddy Kennedy?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Sure. I remember seeing a book about Chappaquiddick on his desk and he was always getting material out of the White House Library and the Library of Congress and--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hi, it's me. I'm still here.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: I'm so glad.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I'd really like to see Mr. Dardis.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: And you will.  But not now.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I called him from Washington. He's the one who asked me to be here at eleven in the morning.

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: I told you, he had to go out on a case.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Could you reach Mr. Dardis by car radio?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: He is not in the car.  Sorry.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mr. Dardis does call in every so often?

turns.speaker: SECRETARY
turns.text: Well of course.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Good. Just tell him I was here, that I'm sorry I missed him--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Donald Segretti?

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I'm Carl Bernstein.  My paper sent me out to see if I couldn't persuade you to go on the record.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: You can't.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mind if I try?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: According to what we've been able to verify, you've been busy.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: I've got a lot of energy.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Listen--we know you're involved in this--we're going to get the story, why not help?

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: They never told me anything except my own role--I had to find out the rest in the papers.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: By "they" you mean...?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: By "they" you mean the White House, don't you?  Your buddy from USC, Dwight Chapin-- he works for the White House.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: I know where Dwight works.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: When did he hire you?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Do you feel much about the things you did?

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: I didn't do anything wrong.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Tell that to Muskie.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: Oh, maybe nickel and dime stuff.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: During the Florida primary, you wrote a letter on Muskie stationery saying Scoop Jackson had a bastard child. You wrote another that said Hubert Humphrey was out with call girls.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: Sometimes it got up to a quarter maybe--  --off the record.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You wrote the Canuck letter--the one where you claimed Muskie slurred the Canadians.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: I didn't.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: But you know who did.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: When you guys print it in the paper, then I'll know.  I'm a lawyer, and I'll probably go to jail, and be disbarred, and what did I do that was so awful?

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: None of it was my idea, Carl--I didn't go looking for the job.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Chapin did contact you then?

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: Sure--off the record.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: On the orders of Haldeman?

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: I don't know anything about Haldeman, except, Dwight's frightened of him-- everybody's frightened of him--Christ, I wish I'd never gotten messed around with this--all I wanna do is sit in the sun; sit, swim, see some girls.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It gets interesting if it was Haldeman, because our word is that when Chapin says something, he's gotten the OK from Haldeman, and when Haldeman says something, he's gotten the OK from the President.

turns.speaker: SEGRETTI
turns.text: Can't help you.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: At USC, you had a word the this-- screwing up the opposition you all did it at college and called it ratfucking.  Ever wonder if Nixon might turn out to be the biggest ratfucker of them all?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Harry, I just talked to a Miami investigator about Barker--

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --so?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I think it might be helpful if you'd send me to Miami.

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: I'm the one sent you to Toronto, Bernstein--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --that was awhile ago--

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --"I think it might be helpful if you'd send me to Toronto." That was your spiel then. "The Lifestyles of Deserters."  I'm still waiting for it.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Down to Miami and back--how much damage can I do?

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: You're the fella who forgot he rented a Hertz car, do I have to tell you they didn't forget to send us the bill?

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --you got more than one source?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --yes--

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: Speak.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We've just been talking to Young--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --he was going to go into law practice with Segretti.

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: And?--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --goddamnit, when's somebody gonna go on the record on this story--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --and we got a guy in Justice--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --Deep Throat?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What's a real denial?

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: If they ever start calling us goddamn liars--  --it's time to start circling the wagons.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: I thought you guys were supposed to be working on this story--  --you think I like being aced out?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --what?--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --it would have been nice to have had this, I sure would have liked to have had this--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --there's nothing new in it--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --it makes the break-in real--it's a major goddamn story--  --I'm not going to kick ass over this, but I'd like you to know I hate getting beat, I just hate it-- don't forget that I hate it--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --if he did it or just said he did it, God knows.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: I could care less about where it happened; what happened is what counts.  Put him on.  Ken, I'm sorry, it was Goddamn Beirut and they were having a crisis, what's up, kid?  Slow down, Ken, you sound frazzled.  A wife and a family and a cat and a dog, right, Ken.  Ken, I would never print that you were in Marilyn's apartment at night-- unless, of course, you force me to.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --Bernstein, are you sure on this story?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Absolutely--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --what about you?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hannah, I never would have bothered you but I'm off to Miami and they're gonna take away my ten speed unless I get it straightened out fast.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Where are your bills, Carl?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Oh, they're here.  I'm keeping much better records now, Hannah.  See?

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Carl, it's a jungle.  I suggest you either pay this immediately or lay in a large supply of candles.  You'd give a stranger the shirt off your back--except it wouldn't be paid for.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hey... very tense.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Lot of pressure at the Star.  Carl, when we got married, you were four thousand dollars in debt; when we split, you were solvent. That may prove to be the outstanding single achievement of my life, and now look at this.  How much did the damn bike cost?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Five hundred; six maybe.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: You're two months behind--you got enough to cover?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I think.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: Give me your checkbook then.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It's right under that pile.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: I thought you had to get to Miami.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: There's always a later plane.

turns.speaker: HANNAH
turns.text: You're a sex junkie, you know that, Carl?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Nobody's perfect.  I'm glad you're out of it, Hannah-- you're a terrific reporter and I turned you into a bookkeeper.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: This is practically a high school reunion for us, Jane--I would have sprung for a classier place.

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: Anyplace really public, they'd know about it--they know everything at the Committee, Carl--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --you don't really think you're being followed?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: This girlfriend of mine at the Committee, the other day she went back to the D.A. to tell the things the FBI didn't ask her. That night, her boss, he knew what she'd done. They control everything; that's how they know it all.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: FBI too?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: You don't believe me? Well, I was working the weekend of the break-in and my God, all the executives were running around like crazy--you had to practically wait in line to use the shredding machine--and when the FBI came to investigate, they never even asked me about it.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: If you don't like it down there, why don't you quit?

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: I don't know what they'd do to me.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hey, easy...

turns.speaker: JANE
turns.text: We're a long way from high school, Carl...  ...and I'm scared.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: You've really got to go.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Just let me get a match.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: But I want you to know that I understand why you're afraid--a lot of good people down there at the Committee are afraid. I'm really sorry for what you're being put through.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: All those articles you people write-- where do you find that stuff?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We don't tell anyone that. Which is why you can talk to us. And if we can't verify what you say someplace else, we don't print it. That's another reason you can relax.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: I'm relaxed--light your cigarette.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You were Hugh Sloan's bookkeeper when he worked for Maurice Stans at Finance, and we were sort of wondering, did you go work for Stans immediately after Sloan quit or was there a time lapse?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: I never worked for Sloan or Stans.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: One minute but then--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --right, right, I've got to go.  Why did you lie just then?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I was just curious--you don't do it well, so I wondered. Have you been threatened, if you told the truth, is that it?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: ...No... never in so many words...

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It's obvious you want to talk to someone--well, I'm someone.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: There are too many people watching me--they know I know a lot--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --it was all in hundreds, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: A lot of it was. I just thought it was sort of an all-purpose political fund--you know, for taking fat cats to dinner, things like that.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Could buy a lot of steaks, 350,000 dollars.

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: I can't be positive that it was used for the break-in but people sure are worried.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Which people?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: The ones who could disburse the money.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who were they?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: There were a group of them--I think five, I don't know their names.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Sloan knew which five, didn't he?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It's awfully hot--  --and you haven't finished telling me about the money--

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: --omigod, there was so much of it, six million came in one two-day period-- six million cash, we couldn't find enough places to put it. I thought it was all legal, I guess I did, til after the break-in, when I remembered Gordon got so much of it.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Gordon Liddy, you mean?

turns.speaker: BOOKKEEPER
turns.text: It was all so crazy--the day after the break-in he gave us a speech, bouncing up and down on his heels in that loony way of his--Gordon told us not to let Jim McCord ruin everything--don't let one bad apple spoil the barrel, he said. You just know that when Gordon Liddy's calling someone a bad apple, something's wrong somewhere.  ...It's all so rotten... and getting worse... and all I care about is Hugh Sloan. His wife was going to leave him if he didn't stand up and do what was right. And he quit. He quit because he saw it and didn't want any part of it.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Think Sloan's being set up as a fall guy for John Mitchell? Sometimes it looks that way.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Why couldn't you have just dialed me from the office, Irwin?

turns.speaker: IRWIN
turns.text: 'Cause I'm not calling out from the phone company anymore--  --I think the place is bugged.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: So tell me about the Times article.

turns.speaker: IRWIN
turns.text: What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: No games, Irwin; give.

turns.speaker: IRWIN
turns.text: My big civil rights buddy--  --boy, if John Mitchell was after your phone records, would you be screaming.  What're you onto?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Something maybe big.

turns.speaker: IRWIN
turns.text: And that makes anything you do OK, is that it?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Just tell me about the goddamn article.

turns.speaker: IRWIN
turns.text: It was accurate, but I can't get a fuller listing for you--all Barker's phone records have been subpoenaed.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who by?

turns.speaker: IRWIN
turns.text: A Miami D.A. The guy doing the investigating is named Martin Dardis.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Irwin? I really feel bad, doing something like this--you know that, don't you?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --then again, maybe things are even worse than we've written--

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: --they're worse. That's why I quit.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Try and understand this. I'm a decent Republican. I believe in Richard Nixon. I worked in the White House four years--so did my wife. What happened on June 17 I don't think the President knew anything about. Some of his men I'm not so sure of.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Do you think the truth will come out at the trial?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: That's another of the things I'm not so sure of.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Because people at the Committee were told to lie to the prosecutors?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: We were never told flat out "Don't talk." But the message was clear.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: To cover up?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Well, they sure didn't ask us to come forward and tell the truth.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: But they both worked at the White House?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I will not talk about the other two.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Kalmbach--Nixon's personal lawyer.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Right.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Then Barker withdrew the 25 thousand in hundred dollar bills and gave it back to Liddy who gave it back to me and I put it in the office safe which was crammed.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Ordinarily, though, what was the procedure?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: Routine--I'd just call John Mitchell over at the Justice Department and he'd say "go ahead, give out the money."

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What happens when the baby comes?

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: We're moving.  I've been looking for a job but it's been... hard. My name's been in the papers too much. Sometimes I wonder if reporters understand how much pain they can inflict in just one sentence. I'm not thinking of myself. But my wife, my parents, it's been very rough on them.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I really can't talk now--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --this'll only take one second--

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: --my wife just had the baby, my in- laws are arriving, I'm trying to get the house in some kind of shape.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: --I'm not your source on that--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --it's gotta be Haldeman--someone from the White House had to be involved--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --that leaves Haldeman, period.

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: I'm not your source on that.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --if we wrote a story that said Haldeman controlled the fund?--

turns.speaker: SLOAN
turns.text: --let me put it this way: I'd have no problem if you did.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: Then it's our asses, isn't it?

turns.speaker: SIMONS
turns.text: And we'll all have to go to work for a living.

turns.speaker: SIMONS
turns.text: Same kind of crap--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --all non-denial denials--we're dirty guys and they doubt we were ever virgins but they don't say the story is inaccurate.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --I don't know, I don't know, it feels thin--

turns.speaker: SIMONS
turns.text: --Christ, I wish I knew if we should print this--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --well shit, we oughtta be tense-- we're about to accuse Mr. Haldeman who only happens to be the second most important man in America of conducting a criminal conspiracy from inside the White House--  --it would be nice if we were right--

turns.speaker: SIMONS
turns.text: --you double-checked both sources?--

turns.speaker: SIMONS
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: My non-denial denial.

turns.speaker: FOREIGN EDITOR
turns.text: I don't think either Metropolitan or National should cover the story.  I don't think we should cover the story, period.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: FOREIGN EDITOR
turns.text: It's not that we're using unnamed sources that bothers me, or that everything we print the White House denies, or that almost no other papers are reprinting our stuff.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: It will, it just hasn't bottomed out yet, give it time.

turns.speaker: FOREIGN EDITOR
turns.text: Ben, Jesus, there are over two thousand reporters in this town, are there five on Watergate? Where did we suddenly get all this wisdom?

turns.speaker: FOREIGN EDITOR
turns.text: Look--why would the Republicans do it? --my God, McGovern is self- destructing before our eyes--just like Muskie did, Humphrey, the bunch of 'em.  Why would the burglars have put the tape around the door instead of up and down unless they wanted to get caught? Why did they take a walkie- talkie and then turn it off, unless they wanted to get caught? Why would they use McCord--the only direct contact to the Republicans?

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: You saying the Democrats bugged themselves?

turns.speaker: FOREIGN EDITOR
turns.text: The FBI thinks it's possible--the Democrats need a campaign issue, corruption's always a good one.  Get off the story, Ben--or put some people on McGovern's finances; fair is fair, even in our business.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I was told by this guy at the White House that Hunt was investigating Teddy Kennedy.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: How senior?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You asking me to disclose my source?

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: Just tell me his title.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I don't know titles.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: Is he on the level of Assistant to the President or not?

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: This is a daily paper, we'll explain it tomorrow.  You're certain on Mitchell?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: He approved the payments to Liddy while he was still Attorney General--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I saw him. He verifies.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: OK.  You're about to write a story that says that the former Attorney General-- the man who represented law in America-- is a crook.  Just be right, huh?

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: I got Clawsen on hold--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --his dialing finger must be falling off--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --what do you think?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --he went to her apartment and he told her--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I'm sure--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: --I'm not sure, it still feels thin--

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: We can't talk inside either?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Electronic surveillance.

turns.speaker: BRADLEE
turns.text: Anything else from Mr. Throat?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Mitchell started the cover-up early, everyone is involved in the cover- up, all the way to the top. The whole U.S. intelligence community is mixed in with the covert activities. The extent of it is incredible.  And people's lives are in danger, maybe including ours.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Mr. Caddy? My name's Bob Woodward, I'm from the Post and I wanted to ask about how you happened to come on this case--

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: --I'm not here.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Douglas Caddy, the attorney of record, when questioned about his presence in the courtroom, denied he was in the courtroom, "I'm not here," Mr. Caddy said.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: Clearly, I am here, but only as an individual, I'm not the attorney of record.  Mr. Rafferty has that position. Whatever you want, you'll have to get from him, I have nothing more to say.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Mr. Rafferty was very helpful. Four Cuban-Americans and this other man, James McCord.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: Look, I told you inside--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --you have nothing more to say, I understand that.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What I don't understand is how you got here.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: I assure you, there's nothing mysterious involved.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Probably you're right, but a little while ago, I was talking to a couple of lawyers who'd been assigned to represent the burglars.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Well, they never would have been assigned if anyone had known the burglars had arranged for their own counsel. And that could only mean the burglars didn't arrange for their own counsel--they never even made a phone call.  So if they didn't ask for you to be here, how did you know to come?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Did you know to come because one of the other men involved in the break- in called you?

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: There is no reason to assume other people were involved.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Your clients were arrested with a walkie-talkie; they didn't need that to talk among themselves.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: They are not my clients.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You're a lawyer and you're here--

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: --I met one of the defendants, Mr. Barker, at a social occasion once--  --I have nothing more to say.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: A Miami social occasion?  Mr. Rafferty told me the Cubans were from Miami.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: Barker's wife called me at three this morning; her husband apparently had told her to call if he hadn't called her by then.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It was really nice of you to come, since you'd only met him once.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: Are you implying you don't believe me?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I have nothing more to say.

turns.speaker: CADDY
turns.text: You don't mind getting on people's nerves, do you?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You claiming it was all a misunderstanding, Ken?

turns.speaker: CLAWSEN
turns.text: Absolutely--Marilyn's gotten it totally wrong--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: She's an awfully good reporter--I can't remember her getting too much wrong before, can you?

turns.speaker: CLAWSEN
turns.text: That's a bullshit question, that's a question straight out of Wichita, Kansas.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Sorry, Ken; listen, one last thing: where did your talk with Berger happen?

turns.speaker: CLAWSEN
turns.text: Where?  What do you mean, where?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Well, was it in a bar, her apartment, some restaurant--

turns.speaker: CLAWSEN
turns.text: --I've completely forgotten where it was, except I know it wasn't her apartment.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --this should take only a minute, Mr. Dahlberg, but we're doing a follow- up on the break-in--  --and I was kind of curious about your check.

turns.speaker: DAHLBERG
turns.text: ...check...?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: The twenty-five thousand dollar one.  The one with your name on it.  In Bernard Barker's Florida account.  Bernard Barker, the Watergate burglar--

turns.speaker: DAHLBERG
turns.text: ...you're definitely doing a story...?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: DAHLBERG
turns.text: I'm a proper citizen, I'm a decent man, I don't do anything that isn't decent or proper.  I know I shouldn't tell you this...

turns.speaker: DAHLBERG
turns.text: That twenty-five thousand dollars is money I collected for Nixon in this year's campaign.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I see. And how do you think it reached Miami?

turns.speaker: DAHLBERG
turns.text: I don't know; I really don't. The last time I saw it was when I was in Washington. I gave it to the Finance department of the Committee to Re- Elect the President. How it got to that burglar, your guess is as good as mine.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: That checks out with our finding, thank you, Mr. Dahlberg.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: I saw the flag signal--what's up?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Nothing, that's the problem--the story's gone underground.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: You thought I'd help out on specifics?  I'll confirm what you get, try to keep you on the right track, but that's all.  Are you guys really working?  How much?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I don't know maybe sixteen, eighteen hours a day--we've got sources at Justice, the FBI, but it's still drying up.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Then there must be something, mustn't there. Look, forget the myths the media's created about the White House-- the truth is, these are not very bright guys, and things got out of hand.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: If you don't like them, why won't you be more concrete with me?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Because the press stinks too--history on the run, that's all you're interested in.  You come up with anything?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: John Mitchell resigned as head of CREEP to spend more time with his family. That doesn't exactly have the ring of truth.  Howard Hunt's been found--there was talk that his lawyer had 25 thousand in cash in a paper bag.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Follow the money. Always follow the money.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: To where?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: This man Gordon Liddy--he's going to be tried along with Hunt and the five burglars--we know he knows a lot, we just don't know what.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: You changed cabs? You're sure no one followed you?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I did everything you said, but it all seemed--

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: --melodramatic?  Things are past that--remember, these are men with switchblade mentalities who run the world as if it were Dodge City.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What's the whole thing about--do you know?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: What I know, you'll have to find out on your own.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Liddy--you think there's a chance he'll talk?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Talk? Once, at a gathering, he put his hand over a candle. And he kept it there. He kept it right in the flame until his flesh seared. A woman who was watching asked, "What's the trick?" And he replied. "The trick is not minding."

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: My turn to keep you waiting.  What's the topic for tonight?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Ratfucking.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: In my day, it was simply called the double cross. I believe the CIA refers to it as Mindfuck. In our context, it simply means infiltration of the Democrats.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I know what it means--Segretti wouldn't go on the record, but if he would, we know he'd implicate Chapin. And that would put us inside the White House.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Yes, the little ratfuckers are now running our government.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Who?--be specific. How high up?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: You'll have to find that out, won't you.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: The slush fund at CREEP financed the ratfucking, we've almost got that nailed down, so--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Did you change cabs?  It didn't work, something moved there--

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: I hope you noticed how coolly I behaved under the threat of discovery.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Do Justice and the FBI know what we know, and why the hell haven't they done anything about it?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: They know, but they focused on the burglary--if it didn't deal with the break-in, they didn't pursue it.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Why didn't they?--who told them not to?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Someone with authority I'd imagine, wouldn't you?  Don't you know what you're onto? Come on.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Mitchell knew then.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Of course--my God, you think something this big just happens? The break-in and the cover up, of course Mitchell knew, but no more than Ehrlichman.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Haldeman too?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: You get nothing from me about Haldeman?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Why did they do all this for Chrissakes?--what were they after?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Total manipulation. I suppose you could say they wanted to subvert the Constitution, but they don't think along philosophical lines.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Talk about Segretti--

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: --don't concentrate on Segretti or you'll miss the overall scheme too.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: There were more then.

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Follow every lead--every lead goes somewhere--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --the Canuck letter--was that a White House operation--

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: --don't you miss the grand scheme too.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: How grand?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Nationwide--my God, they were frightened of Muskie and look who got destroyed--they wanted to run against McGovern, and look who they're running against. They bugged, they followed people, false press leaks, fake letters, they canceled Democratic campaign rallies, they investigated Democratic private lives, they planted spies, stole documents, on and on-- don't tell me you think this was all the work of little Don Segretti.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: And Justice and FBI know all this?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: Yes, yes, everything. There were over fifty people employed by the White House and CREEP to ratfuck-- some of what they did is beyond belief.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Fifty ratfuckers directed by the White House to destroy the Democrats?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: I was being cautious.  You can safely say more then fifty...

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I know, I know, the pressure's off the White House and it's all back on the Post--

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: --you've done worse than let Haldeman slip away, you've got people feeling sorry for him--I didn't think that was possible. A conspiracy like this-- the rope has to tighten slowly around everyone's neck. You build from the outer edges and you go step by step. If you shoot too high and miss, then everybody feels more secure. You've put the investigation back months.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: We know that--and if we were wrong, we're resigning--were we wrong?

turns.speaker: DEEP THROAT
turns.text: You'll have to find that out, won't you?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Hello, I'm Bob Woodward of the Washing Post and...  Mullen and Company Public Relations? Could you tell me when you expect Mr. Hunt?  He is?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Howard Hunt here.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Hi, I'm Bob Woodward of the Post and--

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: --yes, yes, what is it?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I was just kind of wondering why your name and phone number were in the address books of two of the men arrested at Watergate?

turns.speaker: HUNT
turns.text: Good God!

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Your name, please.

turns.speaker: MCCORD
turns.text: James McCord.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Will you step forward, sir.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: And what is your occupation, Mr. McCord?

turns.speaker: MCCORD
turns.text: Security consultant.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: MCCORD
turns.text: Government. Recently retired.

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Where in government?

turns.speaker: MCCORD
turns.text: ...Central... Intelligence... Agency...

turns.speaker: JUDGE
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: MCCORD
turns.text: The C.I.A.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: I'm so glad you could come, Mr.--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I'm Woodward.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: You know, the paper was my father's and my husband's when they were alive and I was thinking back a year or two ago when Ben called me and said he wanted to publish the Pentagon Papers the next day. The Times had already been stopped from publishing anymore of them and all my legal counsel said "don't, don't" and I was frightened but I knew if I said no, I'd lose the whole fifth floor. So we published, and that night, after I'd told Ben to go ahead, I woke up in the darkness and I thought, "Oh my Lord, what am I doing to this newspaper?"  I woke up again last night with that same question.  Are we right on this story?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I think so.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: Are you sure?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: When will you be, do you think?-- when are we going to know it all?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It may never come out.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: Never? Please don't tell me never.  Ben says you've found some wonderful sources.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Some Justice Department lawyers and an FBI man, and some people from the Committee to Re-Elect, yes ma'am.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: And the underground garage one.  Would I know him?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I couldn't say.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: But it's possible.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: You've never told anyone who he is?  But you'd have to tell me if I asked you.  Tell me.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I would, if you really ever wanted to know.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: I really want to know.

turns.speaker: MRS. GRAHAM
turns.text: We're going to need lots of good luck, aren't we?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Nobody ever had too much.

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --you are ignoring the importance of the Dahlberg repercussions--

turns.speaker: NATIONAL EDITOR
turns.text: --nobody gives a shit about the Dahlberg repercussions--

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --quit equivocating, say what you mean--  --our story got Government Accounting to start an audit on CREEP's finances--

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --correction--when you were drinking your lunch at the bar of the Sans Souci--

turns.speaker: NATIONAL EDITOR
turns.text: --this White House guy, a good one, a pro, came up and asked what is this Watergate compulsion with you guys and I said, well, we think it's important and he said, if it's so goddamn important, who the hell are Woodward and Bernstein?

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: Ask him what he's really saying--he means take the story away from Woodstein and give it to his people at the National Desk--

turns.speaker: NATIONAL EDITOR
turns.text: --well, I've got some pretty experienced fellas sitting around, wouldn't you say so?--

turns.speaker: ROSENFELD
turns.text: --absolutely--and that's all they do, sit sit sit--every once in a while, they call up a Senator, some reporting--

turns.speaker: NATIONAL EDITOR
turns.text: --well, what if your boys get it wrong--
